content: mary thomson designs on ravelry 12nd may 2012 crochet bandana cowl this cowl shape is based on the knit version of the bandana cowl http //www purlbee com/bandana-cowl/ which i really loved and wanted to recreate in crochet i prefer a bit of texture in crochet rather than a straightforward single or half double stitch throughout even though it takes a little more concentration when it comes to shaping for that reason i ve used a up and down stitch for some subtle texture without losing the well-defined shape of the scarf i m really pleased with how this has turned out and looks just as good with a multicoloured yarn like this one or in a plain colour finished size length ~15cm ~6 inches increasing to ~28 cm ~11 inches circumference ~ 50 cm 20 inches gauge you can increase or decrease the size of this cowl by changing the number of stitches in the foundation chain but gauge really depends on the yarn used and in the end isn t terribly important the cowl is worked from top down so if you prefer a wider opening then it is easy to adjust hook a 5mm hook was used for this project but i suggest you use whatever hook size is appropriate for the yarn mary thomson designs on ravelry 12nd may 2012 yarn the yarn pictured here is a handspun light worsted weight and all the sizes are based on this weight yarn i ve made another in a standard dk weight yarn and the measurements are quite similar really just a little narrower yardage in total i needed just under 1 skein that is around 70-80m abbreviations american terms british equivalent chain chain chain single_crochet single_crochet double_crochet double_crochet double_crochet treble_crochet bpdc back post double_crochet back post treble_crochet fpdc front post double_crochet front post treble_crochet slip_stitch slip_stitch slip_stitch mary thomson designs on ravelry 12nd may 2012 pattern top edging 1 leaving a few inches of free yarn chain 77 double_crochet in 3rd chain from hook and in each chain across ending with slip_stitch in 2nd chain of turning chain being careful not to twist turn 75st a the free yarn can be used to connect the foundation chain when sewing in the ends during completion of the cowl i find this simpler than trying to slip_stitch the ends of a foundation chain together without twisting 2 ch2 bpdc around first stitch and around each stitch along ending with slip_stitch into last chain of turning chain turn 3 ch2 fpdc around first stitch and around each stitch along ending with slip_stitch into last chain of turning chain turn body of cowl 4 ch2 double_crochet in 1st st *single_crochet in next st double_crochet in next st* repeat between * across ending with slip_stitch in last chain of turning chain turn pattern row 5 repeat row 4 twelve times or until cowl measures ~10 cm/ 4 inches decreases the width is decreased by two stitches on either end of each row
